Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616) 204-6992.

ALLEGATION:
Facility has not submitted records to MDHHS for permanent retention one year
following the final order of adoption as required. There are 2 records that have not
been submitted.
INVESTIGATION:
On 5/23/22 it was reported to DCWL that DHHS had not received two closed
adoption files that were due in 2021. Contact occurred with the complainant to
determine the names on the overdue files.
Chief Administrator (CA)
On 5/23/22 CA was contacted and notified of the investigation. On 6/1/22 an on-site
inspection was completed, and CA was interviewed with supportive information
provided by the Foster Care Supervisor and Business Manager. CA reported
difficulty with taking files to local DHHS offices during the pandemic, as no one was
available at the offices to receive the files.
CA provided the agency policy/procedure regarding sending adoption/foster care
files to DHHS. Currently a monthly report is generated and identifies which files will
2

be due in the next few months. Staff then gather files and prepare them to be sent
by the due date. CA reported this has been their “unofficial” procedure for some
time, but COVID had interfered with this process. The process is now outlined in a
policy/procedure, which will be reviewed with staff.
CA provided the following information for the identified files:
 File one: Due to DHHS December 2021. Sent to DHHS 4/19/22.
 File two: Due to DHHS December 2021. Sent to DHHS 4/19/22.
In addition to these two files, a review of closed adoption files determined there are
currently four adoption files from 2020-2022 that are overdue and need to be sent to
DHHS. There were also fifty-four files from that time period that were submitted to
DHHS late. The agency is in the process of packaging overdue files to submit to the
local DHHS offices.
APPLICABLE RULE
ADM 1030 Disposition of Records for MDHHS- Supervised Children
For both MDHHS and contracted adoption agency cases, the
local MDHHS office or contracted agency must retain all
adoption case records for one year after finalization of the
adoption. One year (between 12-13 months) past the adoption
finalization date, a contracted adoption agency must send the
original record to the local MDHHS office; copies must not be
maintained by the contracted adoption agency; see licensing
rule R400.12713-Adoption Placement Record.
ANALYSIS: A violation was found due to multiple adoption files that were
late or remain overdue to DHHS.
Technical Assistance
It was discussed with the CA there was some confusion about
file retention dates and inclusion of the foster care file, when
sending the adoption file to DHHS. Technical Assistance was
provided regarding FOM 722-15 as it conflicts with Rule 422(4)
regarding file retention. DCWL confirmed that FOM 722-15 must
be followed.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
